Situation1: There is a scheduled family gathering on the calendar.
Expectation2: Review and analyze legal documents and contracts
Situation2: A client has sent a standard contract for a routine service engagement that is not due back for quite some time.
Story: I glanced at the calendar, a bright circle around Saturday reminding me of the family gathering I’d promised to attend. My daughter had called twice, making sure I’d be there to play with the grandkids and share stories over dinner. I could already picture their eager faces, the laughter, the warmth. But as I settled into my chair, my phone buzzed—a client had just emailed a contract for review. It was a standard service agreement, nothing urgent, and the deadline was weeks away. Still, the old habit tugged at me: review it now, get ahead, be thorough. My reputation as a lawyer was built on reliability and promptness. Yet, as a grandparent, I was expected to be present, to give my time and attention freely. The two roles pulled at me, each demanding a different kind of presence. I sat at my desk, the contract open on one screen, the family group chat lighting up on another, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, unsure which to choose.
